titleStmt.title: A machine-readable version of The Puritan or The Widow of Watling Street

publicationStmt.publisher: The puritaine or The vviddovv of VVatling-streete Acted by the Children of Paules. Written by W.S., Imprinted at London : By G. Eld, 1607. Date: 1607 Bib name / number: STC (2nd ed.) / 21531 Bib name / number: Greg, I, 251(a). / Physical description: [62] p. Copy from: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery

sourceDesc.p: Base text from LION via Clip, the 1652 edition, edited to follow The Puritaine or The Widdow of Watling-streete, Acted by the Children of Paules, Written by W. S. (1607), STC21531, dated by the Annals to 1606

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Widow. Sir Godfrey. Edm. Fran. Mol. Pye. Skir. Nich. Sim. Frail. Corp. More than one speaker speaking at once Cap. Penny-Dub. Sir Oliver Muck-hill. Sir Andrew Tip-staff. Officer Puttock Ravenshaw Dog. Servant Gentleman Keep. Sheriff of London. Nob.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.stage: Enter the Lady Widdow-Plus, her two Daughters Franke and Moll, her husbands Brother an old Knight Sir Godfrey, with her Sonne and heyre Maister Edmond, all in mourning apparell, Edmond in a Cypresse Hatte. The Widdow wringing her hands, and bursting out into passion, as newly come from the Buriall of her husband.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: O, that ever I was born, that ever I was born!

sp.speaker: Sir Godfrey.
sp.p: Nay good sister, dear sister, sweet sister, be of good comfort, show yourself a woman, now or never.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, I have lost the dearest man, I have buried the sweetest husband that ever lay by woman.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Nay give him his due, he was indeed an honest, virtuous, discreet wise man, -- he was my Brother, as right, as right.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, I shall never forget him, never forget him, he was a man so well given to a woman -- O!

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Nay, but kind sister, I could weep as much as any woman, but alas our tears cannot call him again: methinks you are well read, sister and know that death is as common as Homo a common name to all men; -- a man shall be taken when he is making water, -- nay, did not the learned Parson Master Pegman tell us even now, that all Flesh is frail, we are born to die, Man has but a time: with such like deep and profound persuasions, as he is a rare fellow you know, and an excellent Reader: and for example, (as there are examples abundance) did not Sir Humfrey Bubble die the other day, there is a lusty Widow, why she cried not above half an hour -- for shame, for shame: then followed him old Master Fulsome the Usurer, there is a wise Widow, why she cried never a whit at all.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O rank not me with those wicked women, I had a husband outshined them all.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Aye that he did in faith, he outshined them all.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Dost thou stand there and see us all weep, and not once shed a tear for thy fathers death? o thou ungracious son and heir thou?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Troth, Mother I should not weep I am sure; I am past a Child I hope, to make all my old School fellows laugh at me; I should be mocked, so I should; pray let one of my sisters weep for me, I will laugh as much for her another time?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O thou past grace thou, out of my sight, thou graceless Imp, thou grievest me more than the death of thy Father? o thou stubborn only Son? hadst thou such an honest man to thy Father -- that would deceive all the world to get riches for thee, and canst thou not afford a little salt water? he that so wisely did quite overthrow the right heir of those Lands, which now you respect not: up every morning betwixt four and five, so duly at Westminster Hall every Term time, with all his Cards and Writings, for thee thou wicked Absalon -- O dear husband!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Weep? quoth he? I protest I am glad he is Churched? for now he is gone I shall spend in quiet.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dear Mother; pray cease, half your tears suffice,
It is time for you to take truce with your eyes,
Let me weep now?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O such a dear Knight! such a sweet Husband have I lost, have I lost? -- if blessed be the Coarse the rain rains upon, he had it, pouring down?

sp.speaker: Sir. God.
sp.p: Sister? be of good cheer, we are all mortal ourselves, I come upon you freshly, I never speak without comfort, hear me what I shall say; -- my brother has left you wealthy, you are rich.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O!

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: I say you are rich? you are also fair.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O!

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Go to, you are fair you cannot smother it, beauty will come to light; nor are your years so far entered with you, but that you will be sought after, and may very well answer another husband; the world is full of fine Gallants, choice enough, sister, -- for what should we do with all our Knights I pray? but to marry rich Widows, wealthy Citizens Widows; lusty fair browed Ladies; go to, be of good comfort I say, leave sobbing and weeping -- yet my Brother was a kind hearted man -- I would not have the Elf see me now? -- come, pluck up a woman's heart -- here stands your Daughters, who be well estated, and at maturity will also be enquired after with good husbands, so all these tears shall be soon dried up, and a better world than ever -- what, Woman? you must not weep still? he is dead, he is buried -- yet I cannot choose but weep for him.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Marry again! no, let me be buried quick then!
And that same part of Quire whereon I tread
To such intent, O may it be my grave:
And that the Priest may turn his wedding prayers,
Even with a breath, to funeral dust and ashes;
sp.p: O, out of a million of millions, I should never find such a husband; he was unmatchable -- unmatchable: nothing was so hot, nor too dear for me, I could not speak of that one thing that I had not, beside, I had keys of all, kept all, received all, had money in my purse, spent what I would, went abroad when I would, came home when I would, and did all what I would: O -- my sweet husband; I shall never have the like.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Sister? never say so, he was an honest Brother of mine, and so, and you may light upon one as honest again, or one, as honest again may light upon you, that is the properer phrase indeed?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Never? O if you love me urge it not,
O may I be the byword of the world,
The common talk at Table in the mouth
Of every Groom and Waiter, if ever more
I entertain the carnal suite of man?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I must kneel down for fashion too?

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.l: And aye, whom never man as yet hath scald
Even in this depth of general sorrow, vow
Never to marry, to sustain such loss,
As a dear husband seems to be, once dead?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I loved my Father well too; but to say,
Nay now, I would not marry for her death,
Sure I should speak false Latin, should I not?
I would as soon vow never to come in Bed:
Tut, Women must live by the quick, and not by the dead.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Dear Copy of my husband, and o let me kiss thee:
Drawing out her Husbands Picture.
How like him is their Model; their brief Picture
Quickens my tears: my sorrows are renewed
At their fresh sight.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Sister --

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Away,
All honesty with him is turned to clay,
O my sweet husband, O --

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My dear Father?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Here is a puling indeed! I think my Mother weeps for all the women that ever buried husbands: for if from time to time all the Widowers tears in England had been bottled up, I do not think all would have filled a three halfpenny Bottle: Alas, a small matter bucks a Handkercher, -- and sometimes the spittle stands too nigh Saint Thomas a Waterings well, I can mourn in good sober sort as well as another? but where I spend one tear for a dead Father, I could give twenty kisses for a quick husband.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, old Sir Godfrey, if thou mayst be proud of it, thou hast a kind loving sister-in-law: how constant? how passionate? how full of the April poor souls eyes are; well, I would my Brother knew of it, he should then know what a kind wife he had left behind him; truth, if it were not for shame that the neighbours at the next Garden should hear me, betwixt joy and grief, I should even cry outright!

sp.speaker: Edmond.
sp.p: So, a fair riddance, my Father is laid in dust, his Coffin and he is like a whole meat pie, and the worms will cut him up shortly: farewell old Dad, farewell; I will be curbed in no more: I perceive a son and heir may quickly be made a fool if he will be one, but I will take another order; -- Now she would have me weep for him forsooth, and why? because he cozened the right heir being a fool, and bestowed those Lands upon me his eldest Son; and therefore I must weep for him, ha, ha: why all the world knows as long as it was his pleasure to get me, it was his duty to get for me: I know the Law in that point, no Attorney can gull me. Well, my Uncle is an old Ass, and an admirable Coxcomb, I will rule the Roast myself, I will be kept under no more, I know what I may do well enough by my Fathers Copy: the Law is in mine own hands now: nay now I know my strength, I will be strong enough for my Mother I warrant you?

div1.stage: Enter George Py-bord a Scholler and a Cittizen and unto him an old Souldier, Peter Skirmish.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: What is to be done now? old Lad of War; thou that wert wont to be as hot as a turn-spit, as nimble as a Fencer, and as lousy as a schoolmaster; now thou art put to silence like a Sectary, -- War sits now like a Justice of peace, and does nothing: where be your Muskets, Caleiurs and Hotshots? in Long lane, at pawn, at pawn; -- Now keys are your only Guns, Key guns, Key guns, and Bawds the Gunners, -- who are your sentinels in peace, and stand ready charged to give warning; with hems, hums, and pocky coughs; only your Chambers are licenced to play upon you, and Drabs enough to give fire to them.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Well, I cannot tell, but I am sure it goes wrong with me, for since the cessure of the wars, I have spent above a hundred crowns out of purse: I have been a soldier any time this forty years, and now I perceive an old Soldier, and an old Courtier have both one destiny, and in the end turn both into hobnails.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Pretty mystery for a Beggar, for indeed a hobnail is the true emblem of a beggars shoe sole;

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I will not say but that War is a bloodsucker, and so ; but in my conscience, (as there is no soldier but has a piece of one, though it be full of holes like a shot Ancient, no matter, it will serve to swear by ) in my conscience, I think some kind of Peace, has more hidden oppressions, and violent heady sins, (the looking of a gentle nature) than a professed war.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Troth, and for mine own part, I am a poor Gentleman, and a Scholar, I have been matriculated in the university, wore out six Gowns there, seen some fools, and some Scholars, some of the City, and some of the Country, kept order, went bareheaded over the Quadrangle, eat my Commons with a good stomach, and Battled with Discretion; at last, having done many slights and tricks to maintain my wit in use (as my brain would never endure me to be idle,) I was expelled the University, only for stealing a Cheese out of Jesus College.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O! there was one Welshman (God forgive him) pursued it hard; and never left, till I turned my staff toward London, where when I came, all my friends were pit-hold, gone to Graves, (as indeed there was but a few left before) then was I turned to my wits, to shift in the world, to tower among Sons and Heirs, and Fools, and Gulls, and Ladies eldest Sons, to work upon nothing, to feed out of Flint, and ever since has my belly been much beholding to my brain: But now to return to you, old Skirmish I say as you say, and for my part wish a Turbulency in the world, for I have nothing to lose but my wits, and I think they are as mad as they will be: and to strengthen your Argument the more, I say an honest war, is better than a bawdy peace: as touching my profession; The multiplicity of Scholars, hatched, and nourished, in the idle Calms of peace, makes them like Fishes one devour another; and the community of Learning has so played upon affections, and thereby almost Religion is come about to Fantasy, and discredited by being too much spoken of -- in so many and mean mouths, I myself being a Scholar and a Graduate, have no other comfort by my learning, but the Affliction of my words, to know how Scholar-like to name what I want, and can call myself a Beggar both in Greek and Latin, and therefore not to cog with Peace, I will not be afraid to say, it is a great Breeder, but a barren Nourisher: a great getter of Children, which must either be Thieves or Rich men, Knaves or Beggars.

sp.speaker: Skirmish.
sp.p: Well, would I had been born a Knave then, when I was born a Beggar, for if the truth were known, I think I was begot when my Father had never a penny in his purse.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Puh, faint not old Skirmish, let this warrant thee, Facilis Descensus Averni it is an easy journey to a Knave, thou mayst be a Knave when thou wilt; and Peace is a good Madam to all other professions, and an arrant Drab to us, let us handle her accordingly, and by our wits thrive in despite of her ; for since the law lives by quarrels, the Courtier by smooth god morrows, and every profession makes itself greater by imperfections, why not we then by shifts, wiles, and forgeries? and seeing our brains are the only Patrimonies, let us spend with judgment, not like a desperate son and heir, but like a sober and discreet Templer, -- one that will never march beyond the bounds of his allowance, and for our thriving means, thus, I myself will put on the Deceit of a Fortune teller, a Fortune teller.

sp.speaker: Skirm.
sp.p: Very proper.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: And you a figure caster, or a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: A Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Let me alone, I will instruct you, and teach you to deceive all eyes, but the Devils.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: O aye, for I would not deceive him if I could choose, of all others.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Fear not I warrant you; and so by those means we shall help one another to Patients, as the condition of the age affords creatures enough for cunning to work upon.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: O wondrous new fools and fresh asses.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O, fit, fit, excellent.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: What in the name of Conjuring?

sp.speaker: Pye-boord.
sp.p: My memory greets me happily with an admirable subject to graze upon. The Lady widow, who of late I saw weeping in her Garden for the death of her Husband, sure she has but a waterish soul, and half of it by this time is dropped out of her eyes: device well managed may do good upon her : it stands firm, my first practise shall be there?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: You have my voice George ?

sp.speaker: Pye-board.
sp.p: She has a gray Gull to her Brother, a fool to her only son, and an ape to her youngest Daughter; -- I overheard them severally, and from their words I will drive my device; and thou old Peter Skirmish shalt be my second in all slights.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Never doubt me George Pye-board, -- only you must teach me to conjure.

div1.stage: Enter Captain Idle, pinioned, & with a guarde of Officers passeth over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Puh, I will perfect thee, Peter:
How now? what is he?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: O George ! this sight kills me,
It is my sworn Brother, Captain Idle

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Captain Idle

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Apprehended for some felonious act or other, he has started out, he has made a Night of it, lacked silver; I cannot but commend his resolution, he would not pawn his buff jerkin, I would either some of us were employed, or might pitch our Tents at Usurers doors, to kill the slaves as they peep out at the Wicket.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Indeed those are our ancient enemies; they keep our money in their hands, and make us to be hanged for robbing of them, but come let us follow after to the Prison, and know the Nature of his offence, and what we can steed him in, he shall be sure of; and I will uphold it still, that a charitable Knave, is better than a soothing Puritan.

div1.stage: Enter at one doore Corporal Oth, a vaine-glorious fellow, and at the other, three of the Widdow Puritaines Servingmen, Nicholas Saint-Tantlings, Simon Saint-Mary-Oueries, and Frailtie in black scuruie mourning coates, and Bookes at their Girdles, as comming from Church.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What Corporal Oath? I am sorry we have met with you next our hearts; you are the man that we are forbidden to keep company withal, we must not swear I can tell you, and you have the name for swearing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Aye, Corporal Oath, I would you would do so much as forsake us sir, we cannot abide you, we must not be seen in your company.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: There is none of us I can tell you, but shall be soundly whipped for swearing.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Why how now? we three? Puritanical Scrape shoes, Flesh on good Fridays; a hand.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Why Nicholas Saint-Tantlings, Simon Saint Mary Ovaries, has the Devil possessed you, that you swear no better, you half christened Catamites, you ungodmothered Varlets, does the first lesson teach you to be proud, and the second to be Coxcombs; proud Coxcombs? not once to do duty to a man of Mark.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: A man of Mark quoth he, I do not think he can show a beggar is Noble.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: A Corporal, a Commander, one of spirit, that is able to blow you up all dry with your Books at your Girdles.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: We are not taught to believe that sir, for we know the breath of man is weak?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Foh, you lie Nicholas; for here is one strong enough; blow us up, quoth he, he may well blow me above twelve-score off of him: I warrant if the wind stood right, a man might smell him from the top of Newgate, to the the Leads of Ludgate?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Sirrah, thou Hollow book of Wax candle.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Aye, you may say what you will, so you swear not.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: I swear by the --

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good Corporal Oath: for if you swear once, we shall all fall down in a sown presently.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: I must and will swear: you quivering Coxcombs, my Captain is imprisoned, and by Vulcan's Leather Codpiece point --

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O Simon, what an oath was there.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: If he should chance to break it, the poor man's Breeches would fall down about his heels, for Venus allows but one point to his hose?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: With these, my Bully feet, I will thump ope the Prison doors, and brain the Keeper with the begging Box, but I will set my honest sweet Captain Idle at liberty.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How, Captain Idle my old Aunts son, my dear Kinsman in Capadochio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Aye, thou Church peeling, thou Holy paring, Religious outside thou? if thou hadst any grace in thee, thou wouldst visit him, relieve him, swear to get him out?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Assure you Corporal indeed la, it is the first time I heard of it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why it now then Marmoset? bring forth thy yearly wages, let not a Commander perish?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: But, if he be one of the wicked, he shall perish.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Well Corporal, I will even along with you, to visit my Kinsman, if I can do him any good, I will, -- but I have nothing for him, Simon Saint Mary Oueris and Frailty, and pray make a lie for me to the Knight my Master, old Sir Godfrey

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A lie? may you lie then?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O aye, we may lie, but we must not swear.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: True, we may lie with our Neighbours wife, but we must not swear we did so.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: O, an excellent Tag of Religion?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O Simon, I have thought upon a sound excuse, it will go currant, say that I am gone to a Fast;

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: To a Fast, very good?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Aye, to a Fast say, with master Ful-bellie the Minister.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Master Ful-bellie? an honest man: he feeds the flock well, for he is an excellent Feeder?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: O Aye, I have seen him eat up a whole Pig, and afterword fall to the potatoes?

div1.stage: Enter Captain Ydle at one door, and old Souldier at the other.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Pray turn the key.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Turn the key I pray?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Who should those be, I almost know their voices? O my friends?
You are welcome to a smelling Room here? you newly took leave of the air, is it not a strange savour?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: As all Prisons have, smells of sundry wretches;
Who though departed, leave their scents behind them,
By Gold Captain, I am sincerely sorry for thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By my troth George I thank thee; but pish, -- what must be, must be.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Captain, what do you lie in for ? is it great? what is your offence?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Faith, my offence is ordinary, -- common? a Highway, and I fear me my penalty will be ordinary and common too, a halter.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay prophecy not so ill, it shall go heard
But I will shift for thy life.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Whether I live or die, thou art an honest George I will tell you -- silver flowed not with me, as it had done, (for now the tide runs to Bawds and flatterers) I had a start out, and by chance set upon a fat steward, thinking his Purse had been as pursy as his body; and the slave had about him but the poor purchase of ten groats: notwithstanding being descried, pursued, and taken, I know the Law is so grim: in respect of many desperate unsettled soldiers, that I fear me I shall dance after their pipe for it.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I am twice sorry for you, Captain: first, that your purchase was so small, and now that your danger is so great.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Push, the worst is but death, -- have you a pipe of Tobacco about you?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I think, I have thereabouts about me!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Here is a clean Gentleman too, to receive?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: Well, I must cast about, some happy slight:
Work brain, that ever didst thy Master right?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Keeper? let the key be turned!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Aye, aye, pray master Keeper give us a cast of your office?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How now? more Visitants? -- what Corporal Oath?

sp.speaker: Pye. Skir.
sp.p: Corporal?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: In prison honest Captain? this must not be?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How do you Captain Kinsman?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Good Coxcomb? what makes that pure starched fool here?

sp.speaker: Nic.
Cap.
sp.l: This is a double torture now, -- this fool by the book
Does vex me more than my imprisonment?
. What meant you Corporal to hook him hither?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Who he? he shall relieve thee, and supply thee,
I will make him do it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fie, what vain breath you spend! he supply? I will sooner expect mercy from a Usurer when my bond is forfeited, sooner kindness from a Lawyer when my money is spent: nay sooner charity from the Devil, than good from a Puritan?I will look for relief from him, when Lucifer is restored to his blood, and in Heaven again!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I warrant my Kinsman is talking of me, for my left ear burns most tyrannically?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Captain Idle? what is he there? he looks like a Monkey upward, and a Crane downward.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Pshaw; a foolish Cousin of mine: I must thank God for him.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why the better subject to work a scape upon ; thou shalt even change clothes with him, and leave him here, and so --

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Push, I published him even now to my Corporal, he will be damned, ere he do me so much good; why I know a more proper, a more handsome device than that, if the slave would be sociable, -- now goodman fleer face?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, my Cozen begins to speak to me now, I shall be acquainted with him again I hope.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Look what ridiculous Raptures take hold of his wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Then what say you to this device, a happy one Captain?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Speak low George, Prison Rats have wider ears than those in Malt-lofts.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Cozen, if it lay in my power, as they say -- to -- do --

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: It would do me an exceeding pleasure indeed, that, but never talk farther of it, the fool will be hanged, ere he it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Pox, I will thump them to it.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why do but try the Fopster, and break it to him bluntly.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And so my disgrace will dwell in his Jaws, and the
slave slaver out our purpose to his Master, for would I were but as sure of it as I am sure he will deny to it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I would be heartily glad, Cozen, if any of my friendships, as they say, might -- stand, ah --

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why, you see he offers his friendship foolishly to you already.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Aye, that is the hell of it, I would he would offer it wisely?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Verily, and indeed la, Cousin --

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I have took note of thy fleers a good while, if thou art minded to do me good? as thou gapest upon me comfortably, and givest me charitable faces? which indeed is but a fashion in you all that are Puritans, wilt soon at night steal me thy Master's chain?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, I shall sown!

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Corporal, he starts already!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I know it to be worth three hundred Crowns, and with the half of that, I can buy my life at a Brokers, at second hand, which now lies in pawn to the Law, if this thou refuse to do, being easy and nothing dangerous, in that thou art held in good opinion of thy Master; why it is a palpable Argument thou holdest my life at no price, and these thy broken and unjointed offers, are but only created in thy lip, now born, and now buried, foolish breath only? what, wilt do it? shall I look for happiness in thy answer?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Steal my Masters Chain quoth he? no, it shall never be said, that Nicholas Saint Tantlings committed Bird-lime!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay, I told you as much; did I not; though he be a Puritan yet he will be a true man?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why Cousin? you know it is written, thou shalt not steal?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why, and fool, thou shalt love thy Neighbour, and help him in extremities?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Mass I think it be indeed; in what Chapter is that, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why in the first of Charity, the second verse.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: The first of Charity, quoth he, that is a good jest, there is no such Chapter in my book!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No, I knew it was torn out of thy Book, and that makes so little in thy heart.

sp.speaker: Pye.
Nic.
sp.p: Pray do not wish me to be hanged, anything else that I can do; had it been to rob, I would have done it, but I must not steal, that is the word the literal, thou shalt not steal; and would you wish me to steal then?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: No faith, that were too much, to speak truth; why wilt thou nim it from him.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: That I will ?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why enough bully; he shall be content with that, or he shall have none; let me alone with him now! Captain, I have dealt with your Kinsman in a Corner; a good, -- kind natured fellow, methinks : go to, you shall not have all your own asking, you shall bate somewhat on it, he is not contented absolutely as you would say to steal the chain from him, -- but to do you a pleasure, he will nim it from him.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Aye, that I will, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Well seeing he will do no more, as far as I see I must be contented with that.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Here is no notable gullery?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay, I will come nearer to you Gentleman? because we will have only but a help and a mirth on it, the knight shall not lose his chain neither, but be only laid out of the way some one or two days?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Aye, that would be good indeed? Kinsman?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: For I have a farther reach to profit us better by the missing of it only, than if we had it outright, as my discourse shall make it known to you? -- when thou hast the chain, do but convey it out at a backdoor into the Garden, and there hang it close in the Rosemary bank, but for a small season; and by that harmless device, I know how to wind Captain Idle, out of prison, the Knight thy Master shall get his pardon, and release him, and he satisfy thy Master with his own chain and wondrous thanks on both hands.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: That were rare indeed la: pray let me know how?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay it is very necessary thou shouldest know, because thou must be employed as an Actor?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: An Actor? O no, that is a Player? and our Parson rails against Players mightily I can tell you, because they brought him drunk upon theStage once, -- as he will be horribly drunk.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Mass I cannot blame him then, poor Church spout.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why as an Intermeddler then?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Aye, that, that.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Irish Give me Audience then? when the old Knight thy Master has raged his fill for the loss of the chain, tell him thou hast a Kinsman in prison, of such exquisite Art, that the devil himself is french Lackey to him, and runs bareheaded by his horse -- belly (when he has one) whom he will cause with most Irish Dexterity to fetch his chain, though it were hid under a mine of sea coal, and never make Spade or Pick-axe his instruments, tell him but this with farther instructions thou shalt receive from me, and thou showest thyself a Kinsman indeed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A dainty Bully.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: An honest -- Bookkeeper.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And my three times thrice honey Cousin.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay grace of God I will rob him of it suddenly? and hang it in the Rosemary bank, but I bear that mind Cousin I would not steal anything, methinks for mine own Father.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: He bears a good mind in that, Captain!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why well said, he begins to be an honest fellow faith.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: In troth he does.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You see Cousin, I am willing to do you any kindness, always saving myself harmless.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Why I thank thee, fare thee well, I shall requite it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: It will be good for thee, Captain, that thou hast such an egregious Ass to thy Cousin.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Aye, is he not a fine fool Corporal?
sp.l: But George thou talkest of Art and Conjuring,
How shall that be?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: Puh, be it not in your care,
Leave that to me and my directions;
Well Captain doubt not thy delivery now,
Even with the vantage man, to gain by prison,
As my thoughts prompt me: hold on brain and plot,
I aim at many cunning far events,
All which I doubt not to hit at length,
I will to the Widow with a quaint assault,
Captain be merry.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Who I? Kerrie merry buff jerkin.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O, I am happy in more slights, and one will knit strong in another, -- Corporal Oath?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ho Bully?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: And thou old Peter Skirmish, I have a necessary task for you both.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Lay it upon George Pye-boord

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Whatever it be, we will manage it.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: I would have you two maintain a quarrel before the Lady Widows door, and draw your Swords in the edge of the Evening: clash a little, clash, clash.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Faugh.
sp.l: Let us alone to make our Blades ring noon,
sp.p: Though it be after Supper.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Know you can;

And out of that false fire, I doubt not but to raise strange belief -- and Captain to countenance my device the better, and grace my words to the Widow, I have a good plain Satin suit, that I had of a young Reveller the other night, for words pass not regarded nowadays, unless they come from a good suite of clothes, which the Fates and my wits have bestowed upon me. Well Captain Idle, if I did not highly love thee, I would never be seen within twelve score of a prison, for I protest at this instant, I walk in great danger of small debts; I owe money to several Hostesses, and you know such ills will quickly be upon a man's Jack.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: True George?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Fare thee well, Captain. Come Corporal and Ancient? thou shalt hear more news next time we greet thee.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: More news?Aye, by yon Bear at bridge foot in heaven shalt thou.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Enough: my friends farewell,
This prison shows as if Ghosts did part in Hell.

div1.stage: Enter Moll youngest Daughter to the Widdow: alone.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Not marry? forswear Marriage? why all women know it is as honourable a thing as to lie with a man; and I to spite my Sisters vow the more, have entertained a suitor already, a fine gallant Knight of the last Feather, he says he will Coach me too, and well appoint me, allow me money to Dice withal, and many such pleasing protestations he sticks upon my lips: indeed his short winded Father in the Country is wondrous wealthy, a most abominable Farmer, and therefore he may do it in time: troth I will venture upon him; women are not without ways enough to help themselves: if he prove wise and good as his word, why I shall love him, and use him kindly; and if he prove an Ass, why in a quarter of an hours warning I can transform him into an Ox; -- there comes in my Relief again.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O, Mistress Moll, Mistress Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: How now? what is the news?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: The Knight your suitor, Sir Iohn Penny-Dub

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Penny-Dub? where? where?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: He is walking in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Has my Mother seen him yet.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O no, she is -- spitting in the Kitchen.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Direct him hither softly, good Frailty, --
I will meet him half way.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: That is just like running a Tilt; but I hope he will break nothing this time.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: It is happiness my Mother saw him not:
O welcome, good Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Penny-Dub.
sp.p: I thank you faith, -- Nay you must stand me, till I kiss you: it is the fashion everywhere in faith, and I came from Court even now.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Nay the Fates forfend that I should anger the fashion?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: Then not forgetting the sweet of new ceremonies, I first fall back, then recovering myself; make my honour to your lip thus: and then accost it.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Trust me, very pretty, and moving, you are worthy of it, sir. --
O my Mother, my Mother, now she is here,

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: We will steal into the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Nay Sister, let Reason rule you, do not play the fool, stand not in your own light, you have wealthy offers, large tenderings, do not withstand your good fortune: who comes a-wooing to you I pray? no small fool, a rich Knight of the City, Sir Oliuer Muck hill, no small fool I can tell you: and furthermore as I heard late by your Maidservants, (as your Maidservants will say to me anything I thank them) both your Daughters are not without Suitors, aye, and worthy ones too? one a Brisk Courtier, Sir Andrew Tip-staffe; suitor afar off to your eldest Daughter, and the third a huge wealthy Farmers Son, a fine young Country Knight, they call him Sir Iohn Penny-Dub, a good name marry, he may have it coined when he lacks money: what blessings are these Sister?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Tempt me not Satan.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Satan? do I look like Satan? I hope the Devil is not so old as I, trow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You wound my senses, Brother, when you name
A suitor to me, -- O I cannot abide it,
I take in poison, when I hear one named.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now Simon? where is my son Edmond?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Verily, Madam, he is at vain Exercise, dripping in the tennis court.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: At tennis court? o, now his father is gone, I shall have no rule with him; o wicked Edmond, I might well compare this with the Prophecy in the Chronicle, though far inferior, as Harry of Monmouth won all, and Harry of Windsor lost all; so Edmund of Bristow that was the Father, got all, and Edmond of London that is his son now, will spend all?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Peace sister, we will have him reformed, there is hope of him yet, though it be but a little.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Forsooth Madam? there are two or three Archers at door, would very gladly speak with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Archers?

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Your Husbands Fletcher I warrant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: O,
Let them come near, they bring home things of his,
Troth I should have forgot them, how now?
Villain, which be those Archers?

div1.stage: Enter the Suiters, Sir Andrew Tipstaffe, Sir Oliver Muck-hill, and Penni-Dub.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Why do you not see them before you? are not these Archers, what do you call them Shooters: Shooters and Archers are all one I hope.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Out ignorant slave.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Nay, pray be patient Lady,
We come in way of honourable love.

sp.speaker: Tipst. Penny.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: To you.

sp.speaker: Tipst. Penny.
sp.p: And to your Daughters?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O why will you offer me this, Gentlemen? indeed I will not look upon you; when the tears are scarce out of mine eyes, not yet washed off from my cheeks, and my dear husbands body scarce so cold as the Coffin, what reason have you to offer it? I am not like some of your Widows that will bury one in the Evening, and be sure to another ere morning? pray away, pray, take your answers good Knights, if you be sweet Knights, I have vowed never to marry; -- and so have my daughters too!

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: aye two of you have, but the third is a good wench!

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Lady, a shrewd answer marry; the best is, it is but the first, and he is a blunt wooer, that will leave for one sharp answer.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: Where be your Daughters Lady, I hope they will give us better encouragements?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Indeed they will answer you so, take it on my word they will give you the very same answer Verbatim truly la.

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: Mum: Moll is a good wench still, I know what she will do?

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Well, Lady, for this time we will take our leaves, hoping for better comfort.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O never, never? if I live these thousand years; if you be good Knights, do not hope; it will be all Vain, Vain, -- look you, put off all your suites, if you come to me again.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Put off all their suites, quoth he? Aye, that is the best wooing of a Widow indeed, when a man is Non-suited, that is, when he is abed with her.

div1.stage: Going out Muckhill and Sir Godfrey.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Sir Godfrey here is twenty Angels more work hard for me; there is life in it yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Fear not Sir Oliuer Muckhill I will stick close for you, leave all with me.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: By your leave Lady Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What another suitor now?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: A suitor, no, I protest Lady? if you would give me yourself I would not be troubled with you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Say you so Sir, then you are the better welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay, Heaven bless me from a Widow, unless I were sure to bury her speedily!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good bluntness: well, your business, sir?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Very needful; if you were in private once.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Needful? Brother, pray leave us ; and you sir.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: I should laugh now, if this blunt fellow should put them all beside the stirrup, and vault into the saddle himself, I have seen as mad a trick.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Now Sir? -- here is none but we-- Daughters forbear.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O no, pray let them stay, for what I have to speak importeth equally to them as to you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then you may stay.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I pray bestow on me a serious ear,
For what I speak is full of weight and fear.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fear?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: aye, if it pass unregarded, and uneffected,
Else peace and joy: -- I pray Attention.
sp.p: Widow, I have been a mere stranger for these parts that you live in, nor did I ever know the Husband of you, and Father of them, but I truly know by certain spiritual Intelligence, that he is in Purgatory.

sp.speaker: Wid.
Pye.
sp.p: Well Lady, in cold blood I speak it, I assure you that there is a Purgatory, in which place I know your husband to reside, and wherein he is like to remain, till the dissolution of the world, till the last general Bonfire: when all the earth shall melt into nothing, and the Seas scald their finny labourers: so long is his abidance, unless you alter the property of your purpose, together with each of your Daughters theirs, that is, the purpose of single life in yourself and your eldest Daughter, and the speedy determination of marriage in your youngest.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: How knows he that, what, has some Devil told him?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Strange he should know our thoughts: --
Why but Daughter, have you purposed speedy Marriage?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: You see she tells you aye, for she says nothing.
sp.p: Nay give me credit as you please, I am a stranger to you, and yet you see I know your determinations, which must come to me metaphysically, and by a supernatural intelligence.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: This puts amazement on me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Know our secrets?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I had thought to steal a marriage, would his tongue
Had dropped out when he blabbed it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But sir, my husband was too honest a dealing man, to be now in any Purgatories --

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: O do not load your conscience with untruths,
It is but mere folly now to guild them over:
That has past but for Copper; Praises here,
Cannot unbind him there: confess but truth,
I know he got his wealth with a hard gripe:
O hardly, hardly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: This is most strange of all, how knows he that ?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: He would eat fools and ignorant heirs clean up ;
And had his drink from many a poor man's brow,
Even as their labour brewed it.
He would scrape riches to him most unjustly;
The very dirt between his nails was ill got
And not his own, -- O
I groan to speak of it, the thought makes me shudder! -- shudder!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It quakes me too, now I think on it -- sir, I am much grieved, that you a stranger, should so deeply wrong my dead husband!

sp.speaker: Pye-board.
sp.p: O?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A man that would keep Church so duly; rise early before his servants, and even for Religious haste, go ungartered, unbuttoned, nay sir Reverence untrust, to Morning Prayer?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O vff.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Dine quickly upon high days, and when I had great guess, would even shame me, and rise from the Table, to get a good seat at an afternoon Sermon.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: There is the devil, there is the devil, true, he thought it Sanctity enough, if he had killed a man, so it had been done in a Pew, or undone his Neighbour, so it had been near enough to the Preacher, O! -- a Sermon is a fine short Cloak of an hour long, and will hide the upper part of a dissembler, -- Church, aye, he seemed all Church, and his conscience was as hard as the Pulpit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I can no more endure this.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: Nor I Widow,
Endure to flatter.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Is this all your business with me?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: No, Lady, it is but the induction to it,
You may believe my strains, I strike all true.
sp.p: And if your conscience would leap up to your tongue, yourself would affirm it, and that you shall perceive I know of things to come, as well as I do of what is present; a Brother of your husbands shall shortly have a loss.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A loss, marry Heaven forfend, Sir Godfrey my Brother!

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay keep in your wonders, till I have told you the fortunes of you all; which are more fearful, if not happily prevented, -- for your part and your Daughters, if there be not once this day some bloodshed before your door, whereof the human creature dies, two of you the elder shall run mad.

sp.speaker: Mother and Frank.
sp.p: O!

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: That is not I yet.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: And with most impudent prostitution, show your naked bodies to the view of all beholders.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Our naked Bodies? fie for shame.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Attend me, and your younger Daughter be stricken dumb.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Dumb? out alas; it is the worst pain of all for a Woman, I had rather be mad, or run naked, or anything: dumb?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Give ear: ere the evening fall upon Hill, Bog, and Meadow, this my speech shall have past probation, and then shall I be believed accordingly.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: If this be true, we are all shamed, all undone.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Dumb? I will speak as much as ever I can possible before evening.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: But if it so it come to pass (as for your fair sakes I wish it may) that this presage of your strange fortunes be prevented by that accident of death and bloodshedding, which I before told you of ; take heed upon your lives, that two of you which have vowed never to marry, seek out husbands with all present speed, and you the third, that have such a desire to outstrip Chastity, look you meddle not with a Husband.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: A double Torment.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: The breach of this keeps your Father in Purgatory and the punishments that shall follow you in this world, would with horror kill the ear should hear them related.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marry? why I vowed never to marry.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And so did I.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And I vowed never to be such an Ass, but to marry: what a cross Fortune is this?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Ladies, though I be a Fortune teller, I cannot better Fortunes, you have them from me as they are revealed to me: I would they were to your tempers, and fellows with your bloods, that is all the bitterness I would you.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: O! it is a just vengeance, for my Husbands hard purchases.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: I wish you to bethink yourselves, and leave them.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will to Sir Godfrey my Brother, and acquaint him with these fearful presages.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: For, Mother, they portend losses to him.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: O aye, they do, they do;
If any happy issue crown thy words,
I will reward thy cunning.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: It is enough, Lady,
I wish no higher.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Dumb? and not Marry? worse,
Neither to speak, nor kiss, a double curse.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: So, all this comes well about yet, I play the Fortune teller, as well as if I had had a Witch to my Grandam: for by good happiness, being in my Hostesses Garden, which neighbours the Orchard of the Widow, I laid the hole of mine ear to a hole in the wall, and heard them make these Vows, and speak those words upon which I wrought these advantages; and to encourage my forgery the more, I may now perceive in them a natural simplicity which will easily swallow an abuse, if any covering be over it: and to confirm my former presage to the Widow, I have advised old Peter Skirmish the Soldier, to hurt Corporal Oath upon the Leg, and in that hurry, I will rush amongst them, and instead of giving the Corporal some Cordial to comfort him, I will pour into his mouth a potion of a sleepy nature, and make him seem as dead; for the which the old Soldier being apprehended, and ready to be born to execution, I will step in, and take upon me the cure of the dead man, upon pain of dying the condemneds death: the Corporal will wake at his minute, when the sleepy force hath wrought itself, and so shall I get myself into a most admired opinion, and under the pretext of that cunning, beguile as I see occasion: and if that foolish Nicholas Saint Tantlings keep true time with the Chain, my plot will be sound, the Captain delivered, and my wits applauded among Scholars and Soldiers forever.

div1.stage: Enter Nicholas Saint Tantlings, with the Chaine.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, I have found an excellent advantage to take away the chain, my Master put it off even now, to say on a new Doublet, and I sneaked it away by little and little, most Puritanically? we shall have good sport anon when has missed it, about my Cozen the Conjurer; the world shall see I am an honest man of my word, for now I am going to hang it between Heaven and Earth among the Rosemary branches.

div1.stage: Enter Simon Saint Mary-Oueries, and Frailty.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Sirrah Simon Saint Mary-Oueries my Mistress sends away all her suitors, and puts fleas in their ears.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Frailty ? she does like an honest, chaste, and virtuous woman; for Widows ought not to wallow in the puddle of Iniquity.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Yet Simon, many Widows will it, whatso comes of it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: True Frailty, their filthy flesh desires a Conjunction Copulative; what strangers are within, Frailty?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: There is none Simon? but master Pilfer the Tailor: he is above with Sir Godfeie praising of a Doublet: and I must trudge anon to fetch Master Sudds the Barber!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Master Suds, a good man, he washes the sins of the Beard clean.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: How now, creatures? what is o'clock?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Why do you take us to be Jack of the Clock house?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I say again to you what is o'clock?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly la, we go by the Clock of our Conscience, all worldly Clocks we know go false, and are set by drunken Sextons.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Then what is o'clock in your Conscience? -- O, I must break off, here comes the Corporal -- hum, hum: -- what is o'clock?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: O'clock? why past seventeen.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Past seventeen? nay, he has met with his match now, Corporal Oath will fit him.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Thou dost not balk or baffle me, dost thou? I am a Soldier -- past seventeen.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: aye, thou art not angry with the figures art thou? I will prove it unto thee, twelve and one is thirteen I hope, two fourteen, three fifteen, four sixteen, and five seventeen, then past seventeen, I will take the Dials part in a just cause.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I say it is but past five then.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: I will swear it is past seventeen then: dost thou not know numbers? canst thou not cast?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Cast? dost thou speak of my casting in the street?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: aye, and in the Market place.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Clubs, Clubs, Clubs.

sp.speaker: Frail.
Cap.
sp.p: O Villain, thou hast opened a vain in my Leg.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: How now, for shame, for shame, put up, put up.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By yon blew Welkin, it was out of my part George, to be hurt on the Leg.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O peace now -- I have a Cordial here to comfort thee.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Down with them, down with them, lay hands upon the villain.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Lay hands on me?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: I will not be seen among them now.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I am hurt, and had more need have Surgeons,
Lay hands upon me then, rough Officers.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Go carry him to be dressed then:
This mutinous Soldier shall along with me to prison.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: To prison? where is George.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: So,
All lights as I would wish, the amazed Widow,
Will plant me strongly now in her belief,
And wonder at the virtue of my words:
For the event turns these presages from them,
Of being mad and dumb, and begets joy
Mingled with admiration: these empty creatures,
Soldier and Corporal, were but ordained
As instruments for me to work upon.
Now to my Patient, here is his Potion.

div1.stage: Enter the Widdow with her two Daughters.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: O wondrous happiness, beyond our thoughts!
O lucky fair event! I think our fortunes
Were blessed even in our Cradles: we are quited
Of all those shameful violent presages
By this rash bleeding chance: go Frailty run, and know
Whether he be yet living, or yet dead,
That here before my door received his hurt.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Madam, he was carried to the superior, but if he had no money when he came there, I warrant he is dead by this time.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Sure that man is a rare fortune teller, never looked upon our hands, nor upon any mark about us, a wondrous fellow surely.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I am glad I have the use of my tongue yet, though of nothing else, I shall find the way to marry too, I hope shortly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O where is my Brother sir Godfrey I would he were here, that I might relate to him how prophetically the cunning Gentleman spoke in all things.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Godfrey in a rage.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: O my Chain, my Chain, I have lost my Chain, where be these Villains, Varlets?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, he has lost his Chain.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: My Chain, my Chain.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Brother, be patient, hear me speak, you know I told you that a Cunning man told me, that you should have a loss, and he has prophesied so true.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Out, he is a Villain to prophecy of the loss of my Chain, it was worth above three hundred Crowns, -- besides it was my Fathers, my Fathers Fathers, my Grandfathers huge Grandfathers: I had as live have lost my Neck, as the Chain that hung about it; O my Chain, my Chain.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, Brother, who can be against a misfortune, it is happy it was no more.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: No more! O goodly godly sister, would you had me lost more? my best Gown too, with the Cloth of gold lace? my holiday Gascoines, and my Jerkin set with Pearl? no more!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, Brother, you can read. --

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: But I cannot read where my Chain is: what strangers have been here? you let in strangers, Thieves and Catchpoles: how comes it gone? there was none above with me but my Taylor, and my Taylor will not -- steal I hope?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: No, he is afraid of a Chain.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now, sirrah? the news?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O, Mistress, he may well be called a Corporal now, for his Corpse are as dead as a cold Capons?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: More happiness.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Sirrah, what is this to my Chain? where is my Chain, knave?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Your Chain, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: My Chain is lost, Villain.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: I would he were hanged in Chains that has it then for me: Alas, sir, I saw none of your Chain since you were hung with it yourself.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.l: Out varlet? it had full three thousand Links,
I have oft told it over at my prayers:
Over and over, full three thousand Links.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Had it so, sir, sure it cannot be lost then; I will put you in that comfort.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Why? why?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Why if your Chain had so many Links, it cannot choose but come to light.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Delusion. Now, long Nicholas where is my Chain.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why about your neck, is it not, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: About my neck, Varlet? my Chain is lost, It is stole away, I am robbed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, Brother, show yourself a man.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: If it be lost or stole, if he would be patient, Mistress, I could bring him to a Cunning Kinsman of mine that would fetch it again with a Sesarara.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Canst thou? I will be patient, say, where dwells he?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Marry he dwells now, sir, where he would not dwell if he could choose, in the Marshalsea sir; but he is an excellent fellow if he were out: has travelled all the world over, he, and been in the seven and twenty Provinces: why he would make it be fetched, sir, if it were rid a thousand mile out of town.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: An admirable fellow, what lies he for ;

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why he did but rob a Steward of ten groats the other night, as any man would have done, and there he lies for it.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.l: I will make his peace, a trifle, I will get his pardon,
Besides a bountiful reward, I will about it,
But see the Clerks, the Justice will do much;
I will about it straight, good sister pardon me,
All will be well I hope, and turn to good,
The name of Conjurer has laid my blood.

div1.stage: Enter two Serieants to arrest the Scholer George Pyeboord.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: His Hostesses where he lies will trust him no longer, she hath feed me to arrest him; if you will accompany me, because I know not of what nature the Scholar is, whether desperate or swift, you shall share with me, Sergeant Raven-shaw I have the good Angel to arrest him.

sp.speaker: Raven.
sp.p: Troth I will take part with thee then, Sergeant, not for the sake of the money so much, as for the hate I bear to a Scholar: why, Sergeant, it is natural in us you know to hate Scholars: natural besides, they will publish our imperfections, knaveries, and Conveyances upon Scaffolds and Stages.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: aye, and spitefully too; troth I have wondered how the slaves could see into our breasts so much, when our Doublets are buttoned with Pewter.

sp.speaker: Raven.
sp.p: aye, and so close without yielding: o, their parlous fellows, they will search more with their wits, than a Constable with all his Officers.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Whist, whist, whist, Yeoman Dogson, Yeoman Dogson,

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Ha? what says Sergeant?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Is he in the Apothecaries shop still,

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: aye, aye.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: have an eye, eye.

sp.speaker: Raven.
sp.p: The best is Sergeant if he be a true Scholar he wears no weapon I think.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: No, no, he wears no weapon.

sp.speaker: Raven.
sp.p: Mass, I am right glad of that : it has put me in better heart; nay if I clutch him once, let me alone to drag him if he be stiff necked; I have been one of the six myself, that has dragged as tall men of their hands, when their weapons have been gone, as ever bastinadoed a Sergeant -- I have done I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Ho.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: He is coming out single.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Peace, peace, be not too greedy, let him play a little, let him play a little, we will jerk him up of a sudden, I have fished in my time.

sp.speaker: Raven.
sp.p: aye and caught many a fool Sergeant.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I parted now from Nicholas: the chain is couched,
And the old Knight has spent his rage upon it,
The Widow holds me in great admiration
For cunning Art : amongst joys I am even lost,
For my device can no way now be crossed,
And now I must to prison to the Captain, and there --

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I arrest you sir.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O -- I spoke truer than I was aware, I must to prison indeed.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: They say you are a scholar, nay sir -- Yeoman Dogson, have care to his arms -- you will rail against Sergeants, and stage them: you tickle their vices.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay use me like a Gentleman, I am little less.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: You a Gentleman? that is a good Jest in faith; can a Scholar be a Gentleman, -- when a Gentleman will not be a Scholar; -- look upon your wealthy Citizens Sons, whether they be Scholars or no, that are Gentlemen by their Fathers Trades: a Scholar a Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay, let Fortune drive all her stings into me, she cannot hurt that in me, a Gentleman, is Accidens inseparabile to my blood.

sp.speaker: Raven.
sp.p: A rabblement, nay you shall have a bloody rabblement; upon you I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Go, Yeoman Dogson before, and Enter the Action in the Counter.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Pray do not hand me cruelly, I will go,
Whether you please to have me.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O, he is tame, let him loose Sergeant.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Pray at whose Suit is this?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Why, at your Hostesses Suite where you lie, Misters Cunnyburrow for bed and board, the sum four pound five shillings and five pence.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I know the sum too true, yet I presumed
Upon a farther day; well, it is my stars:
And I must bear it now, though never harder.
I swear now, my device is crossed indeed.
sp.p: Captain must lie by it: this is Deceits seed.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Come, come away.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Pray give me so much time as to knit my garter, and I will away with you.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Well, we must be paid for this waiting upon you, this is no pains to attend thus.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: I am now wretched, and miserable, I shall never recover of this disease: hot Iron gnaw their fists: they have struck a Fever into my shoulder, which I shall never shake out again I fear me, till with a true Habeas Corpus the Sexton remove me, o if I take prison once, I shall be pressed to death with Actions, but not so happy as speedily; perhaps I may be forty year a-pressing till I be a thin old man, that looking through the grates, men may look through me; all my means is confounded, what shall I do? has my wit served me so long, and now give me the slip (like a trained servant) when I have most need of them: no device to keep my poor carcase from these Puttocks -- yes, happiness, have I a paper about me now? yes too, I will try it, it may hit, Extremity is Touchstone unto wit, aye, aye.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: 'Sfoot how many yards are in thy Garters, that thou art so lo long a-tying of them? come away sir.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Troth Sergeant I protest; you could never have took me at a worse time, for now at this instant, I have no lawful picture about me.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: 'Slid how shall we come by our fees then.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: We must have fees, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: I could have wished in faith, that you had took me half an hour hence for your own sake, for I protest if you had not crossed me, I was going in great joy to receive five pound of a Gentleman, for the Device of a Mask here, drawn in this paper but now, come, I must be contented, it is but so much lost, and answerable to the rest of my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Why how far hence dwells that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: aye, well said Sergeant, it is good to cast about for money.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Speak, if it be not far --

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: We are but a little past it, the next street behind us.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: 'Slid we have waited upon you grievously already, if you will say you will be liberal when you have it, give us double fees, and spend upon us, why we will show you that kindness, and go along with you to the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: aye well said still Sergeant, urge that.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Troth if it will suffice, it shall all be among you, for my part I will not pocket a penny, my Hostess shall have her four pound five shillings, and bate me the five pence, and the other fifteen shillings I will spend upon you.

sp.speaker: Ravinish.
sp.p: Why now thou art a good Scholar.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: An excellent Scholar in faith; has proceeded very well a-late; come, we will along with you.

div1.stage: Exeunt with him, passing in they knock at the doore with a knocker withinside.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Who knocks, who is at door? we had need of a Porter.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: A few friends here. -- pray is the Gentleman your Master within?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes, is your business to him?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: aye, he knows it, when he sees me:
I pray you, have you forgot me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Aye by my troth, sir, pray come near, I will in and tell him of you, please you to walk here in the Gallery till he comes.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: We will attend his worship, -- worship I think, for so much the posts at his door should signify, and the fair coming in, and the wicket, else I neither knew him nor his worship, but it is happiness he is within doors, whatsoever he be, if he be not too much a formal Citizen, he may do me good: Sergeant and Yeoman, how do you like this house, is it not most wholesomely plotted?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Troth prisoner, an exceeding fine house.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Yet I wonder how he should forget me, for he never knew me: no matter, what is forgot in you, will be remembered in your Master.
sp.l: A pretty comfortable room this methinks:
You have no such rooms in prison now?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O dog holes to it.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Dog holes indeed -- I can tell you I have great hope to have my Chamber here shortly, nay and diet too, for he is the most free heartedest Gentleman where he takes: you would little think it? and what a fine Gallery were here for me to walk and study, and make verses.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O it stands very pleasantly for a Scholar.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Look what maps, and pictures, and devices, and things, neatly, delicately? Mass here he comes, he should be a Gentleman, I like his Beard well; -- All happiness to your worship.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You are kindly welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: A simple salutation.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Mass it seems the Gentleman makes great account of him.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I have the thing here for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: I beseech you conceal me sir, I am undone else, -- I have the Mask here for you sir, Look you sir, -- I beseech your worship, first to pardon my rudeness, for my extremes makes me bolder than I would be; I am a poor Gentleman and a Scholar, and now most unfortunately fallen into the Fangs of unmerciful Officers, arrested for debt, which though small, I am not able to compass, by reason I am destitute of lands, money, and friends, so that if I fall into the hungry swallow of the prison, I am like utterly to perish, and with fees and extortions be pinched clean to the bone: Now, if ever pity had interest in the blood of a Gentleman, I beseech you vouchsafe but to favour that means of my escape, which I have already thought upon.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Go forward.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I warrant he likes it rarely.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: In the plunge of my extremities, being giddy, and doubtful what to do; at last it was put in my labouring thoughts, to make happy use of this paper, and to blear their unlettered eyes, I told them there was a Device for a Mask drawn in it, and that (but for their interception,) I was going to a Gentleman to receive my reward for it: they greedy at this word, and hoping to make purchase of me, offered their attendance, to go along with me, my hap was to make bold with your door, sir, which my thoughts showed me the most fairest and comfortablest entrance, and I hope I have happened right upon understanding, and pity: may it please your good worship then, but to uphold my Device, which is to let one of your men put me out at a backdoor, and I shall be bound to your worship forever.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: By my troth, an excellent device.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: An excellent Device he says; he likes it wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: On my faith, I never heard a better.

sp.speaker: Raven.
sp.p: Hark, he swears he never heard a better, Sergeant.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O there is no talk of it, he is an excellent Scholar, and especially for a Mask.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Give me your Paper, your Device; I was never better pleased in all my life: good wit, brave wit, finely wrought, come in sir, and receive your money, sir.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: I will follow your good Worship, --
You heard how he liked it now?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Puh, we know he could not choose but like it: go thy ways, thou art a fine witty fellow in faith, thou shalt discourse it to us at the Tavern anon, wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: aye, aye, that I will, -- look Sergeants, here are Maps, and pretty toys, be doing in the mean time, I shall quickly have told out the money, you know.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Go, go, little villain, fetch thy chink, I begin to love thee, I will be drunk tonight in thy company.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: This Gentleman I may well call a part
Of my salvation, in these earthly evils,
sp.p: For he has saved me from three hungry Devils.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Sirrah Sergeant, these Maps are pretty painted things, but I could never fancy them yet, methinks they are too busy, and full of Circles and Conjurations; they say all the world is in one of them, but I could never find the Counter in the Poultry.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I think so : how could you find it? for you know it stands behind the houses.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Mass that is true, then we must look on the backside for it: 'sfoot here is nothing, all is bare.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I warrant thee that stands for the Counter, for you know there is a company of bare fellows there.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Faith like enough, Sergeant? I never marked so much before. Sirrah Sergeant, and Yeoman, I should love these Maps out of cry now, if we could see men peep out of door in them, o we might have them in a morning to our Breakfast so finely, and never knock our heels to the ground a whole day for them.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.l: Aye marry sir, I had buy one then myself.
But this talk is by the way, where shall us sup tonight,
Five pound received, let us talk of that,
sp.p: I have a trick worth all, you two shall bear him to the Tavern, whilst I go close with his Hostess, and work out of her, I know she would be glad of the sum, to finger money; because she knows it is but a desperate debt, and full of hazard, what will you say if I bring it to pass that the Hostess shall be contented with one half for all, and we to share the other five shillings, Bullies.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Why I would call thee King of Sergeants, and thou shouldest be Chronicled in the Counter Book forever.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Well, put it to me, we will make a Night of it in faith.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: 'sfoot, I think he receives more money, he stays so long.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: He tarries long indeed, maybe I can tell you, upon the good liking of it the Gentleman may prove more bountiful.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: That would be rare, we will search him.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Nay be sure of it, we will search him, and make him light enough.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: O here comes the Gentleman, by your leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: God you god den sirs, -- would you speak with me;

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: No, not with your worship, sir; only we are bold to stay for a friend of ours, that went in with your worship.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Who? not the Scholar?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Yes, even he, if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Did he make you stay for him? he did you wrong then: why, I can assure you he is gone above an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I paid him his money, and my man told me he went out at backdoor.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Backdoor?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: He was our prisoner sir, we did arrest him.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What he was not? you the Sheriffs Officers -- you were to blame then,
Why did you not make known to me as much;
I could have kept him for you, I protest,
He received all of me in Britain Gold,
Of the last coining.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Vengeance dog him with it.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: 'sfoot has he gulled us so ?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Where shall we sup now, Sergeants?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Sup Simon now, eat Porridge for a month.

Well, we cannot impute it to any lack of goodwill in your Worship, -- you did but as another would have done, it was our hard fortunes to miss the purchase, but if ever we clutch him again, the Counter shall charm him.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: The Hole shall rot him.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: So,
Vex out your Lungs without doors, I am proud,
It was my hap to help him, it fell fit,
He went not empty neither for his wit:
Alas poor wretch, I could not blame his brain,
To labour his delivery, to be free,
From their unpitying fangs, -- I am glad it stood,
Within my power to do a Scholar good.

div1.stage: Enter in the Prison, meeting George and Captain, George coming in muffled.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How now, who is that ? what are you?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: The same that I should be, Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: George Pye-boord, honest George? why camest thou in half faced, muffled so ?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O Captain, I thought we should never have laughed again, never spent frolic hour again.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why? why?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: I coming to prepare thee, and with news
As happy as thy quick delivery,
Was traced out by the sent, arrested, Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Arrested George,

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Arrested; guess, guess, how many Dogs do you think I had upon me?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Dogs? I say? I know not.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Almost as many as George Stone the Bear:
Three at once, three at once.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How didst thou shake them off then?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: The time is busy, and calls upon our wits, let it suffice,
Here I stand safe, and scaped by miracle:
Some other hour shall tell thee? when we will steep
Our eyes in laughter: Captain my device
Leans to thy happiness, for ere the day
Be spent to the Girdle, thou shalt be set free:
The Corporal is in his first sleep, the Chain is missed,
Thy Kinsman has expressed thee, and the old Knight
With Palsy hams now labours thy release.
What rests, is all in thee, to Conjure, Captain?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Conjure? 'sfoot George you know the devil of conjuring I can conjure.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: The Devil of conjuring, nay by my fay, I had not have thee do so much Captain, as the devil of conjuring: look here, I have brought thee a circle ready charactered and all.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: 'sfoot George, art in thy right wits, dost know what thou sayst? why dost talk to a Captain of conjuring: didst thou ever hear of a Captain conjure in thy life, dost call it a Circle, it is too wide a thing methinks; had it been a lesser Circle, then I knew what to have done.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why every fool knows that Captain: nay then I will not cog with you, Captain, if you will stay and hang the next Sessions you may.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No, by my faith George, come, come, let us to conjuring, let us to conjuring.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: But if you look to be released, as my wits have took pain to work it, and all means wrought to farther it, besides to put crowns in your purse, to make you a man of better hopes, and whereas before you were a Captain or poor Soldier, to make you now a Commander of rich fools, (which is truly the only best purchase peace can allow you) safer than Highways, Heath, or Cunny-groues, and yet a far better booty; for your greatest thieves are never hanged, never hanged; for why? they are wise, and cheat within doors; and we geld fools of more money in one night, than your false tailed Gelding will purchase in a twelve-months running, which confirms the old Bedlams saying, he is wisest, that keeps himself warmest, that is, he that robs by a good fire.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well opened in faith George, thou hast pulled that saying out of the husk.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Captain Idle, It is no time now to delude or delay, the old Knight will be here suddenly, I will perfect you, direct you, till you the trick of it: it is nothing.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'sfoot George, I know not what to say to it, conjure? I shall be hanged ere I conjure.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay tell not me of that Captain, you will never conjure after you are hanged I warrant you, look you, sir, a parlous matter? sure, first to spread your circle upon the ground, then with a little conjuring ceremony, as I will have an Hackney man's wand silvered over on purpose for you, then arriving in the circle, with a huge word, and a great trample, as for instance: have you never seen a stalking, king stamping Player, that will raise a tempest with his tongue, and thunder with his heels?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O yes, yes, yes; often, often.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why be like such a one? for anything will blear the old Knights eyes: for you must note, that he will never dare to venture into the room, only perhaps peep fearfully through the Key hole, to see how the Play goes forward.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, I may go about it when I will, but mark the end of it, I shall but shame myself in faith George, speak big words, and stamp and stare, if he look in at Keyhole, why the very thought of that would make me laugh outright, and spoil all: nay I will tell thee George, when I apprehend a thing once, I am of such a laxative laughter, that if the Devil himself stood by, I should laugh in his face.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Puh, that is but the babe of a man, and may easily be hushed, as to think upon some disaster, some sad misfortune, as the death of thy Father in the Country.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: 'sfoot, that would be the more to drive me into such an ecstasy, that I should near lyn laughing.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why then think upon going to hanging else.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Mass that is well remembered, now I will do well, I warrant thee, never fear me now: but how shall I do George, for boisterous words, and horrible names?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Puh, any fustian invocations, Captain, will serve as well as the best, so you rant them out well, or you may go to a Apothecaries shop, and take all the words from the Boxes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Troth, and your say true George, there is strange words enough to raise a hundred Quack salvers, though they be never so poor when they begin? but here lies the fear of it, how in this false conjuration, a true Devil should pop up indeed.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: A true Devil, Captain? why there was never such a one, nay faith he that has this place, is as false a Knave as our last Churchwarden.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Then he is false enough a-conscience in faith George,

sp.speaker: Crie prisoners
