sp.p: Good Gentlemen over the way, send your relief:
Good Gentlemen over the way, -- Good sir Godfrey

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: He is come, he is come.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Master, that is my Kinsman yonder in the Buff jerkin -- Kinsman, that is my Master yonder in the Taffeta Hat -- pray salute him entirely?

div1.stage: They salute: and Pye-boord salutes Maister Edmond.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Now my friend.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: May I partake your name, sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My name is Master Edmund

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Master Edmond -- are you not a Welshman, sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: A Welshman? why?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Because Master is your Christen name, and Edmond your surname.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: O no : I have more names at home, Master Edmond Plus is my full name at length.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O cry you mercy sir?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I understand that you are my Kinsman's good Master, and in regard of that, the best of my skill is at your service: but had you fortuned a mere stranger, and made no means to me by acquaintance, I should have utterly denied to have been the man; both by reason of the Act past in Parliament against Conjurers and Witches, as also, because I would not have my Art vulgar, trite, and common.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: I much commend your care therein good Captain Conjurer, and that I will be sure to have it private enough, you shall it in my Sisters house, -- mine own house I may call it, for both our charges therein are proportioned.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Very good, sir, -- what may I call your loss, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: O you may call it a great loss sir, a grievous loss, sir, as goodly a Chain of Gold, though I say it, that wore it: how sayst thou, Nicholas?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O it was as delicious a Chain of Gold, Kinsman you know, --

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: You know? did you know it, Captain?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Trust a fool with secrets? -- Sir he may say I know: his meaning is, because my Art is such, that by it I may gather a knowledge of all things. --

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Aye very true.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A pox of all fools -- the excuse stuck upon my tongue like Ship pitch upon a Mariners Gown, not to come off in haste -- byrLady, Knight, to lose such a fair Chain of Gold, were a foul loss: Well, I can put you in this good comfort on it, if it be between heaven and earth, Knight, I will have it for you?

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: A wonderful Conjurer, -- O aye, it is between heaven and earth I warrant you, it cannot go out of the Realm, -- I know it is somewhere above the earth.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: aye, nigher the earth than thou wottest on.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: For first my Chain was rich, and no rich thing shall enter into heaven, you know.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: And as for the Devil, Master, he has no need of it, for you know he has a great Chain of his own.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Thou sayst true Nicholas, but he has put off that now, that lies by him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Faith Knight, in few words, I presume so much upon the power of my Art, that I could warrant your Chain again.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O dainty Captain!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Marry it will cost me much sweat, I were better go to sixteen hothouses.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: aye, good man, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Beside great vexation of Kidney and Liver.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, it will tickle you hereabouts, Cousin, because you have not been used to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: No ? have you not been used to it, Captain?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Plague of all fools still; -- indeed Knight I have not used it a good while, and therefore it will strain me so much the more, you know.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O it will, it will.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What plunges he puts me to ? were not this Knight a fool, I had been twice spoiled now; that Captain is worse than accursed that has an Ass to his Kinsman, 'sfoot I fear he will drivel it out before I come to it. -- Now sir, -- to come to the point indeed, -- you see I stick here in the jaw of the Marshalsea and cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Tut tut, I know thy meaning, thou wouldst say thou art a prisoner, I tell thee thou art none.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How, none? why is not this the Marshalsea

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: wilt hear me speak? I heard of thy rare Conjuring:
My Chain was lost, I sweat for thy release,
As thou shalt do the like at home for me:
sp.p: Keeper.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Speak, is not this man free?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yes, at his pleasure, Sir, the fee is discharged.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Go, go, I will discharge them, I.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I thank your Worship.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Now, trust me, you are a dear Knight; kindness unexpected, o there is nothing to a free Gentleman. -- I will Conjure for you, sir, till Froth come through my Buff jerkin.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Nay, then thou shalt not pass with so little a bounty, for at the first sight of my Chain again, -- Forty five Angels shall appear unto thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: It will be a glorious show, in faith Knight, a very fine show; but are all these of your own house? are you sure of that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: aye, aye, no, no ; what is he yonder talking with my wild Nephew, pray heaven he give him good counsel.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Who, he? he is a rare friend of mine, an admirable fellow, Knight, the finest Fortune teller.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O! it is he indeed that came to my Lady sister, and foretold the loss of my Chain; I am not angry with him now, for I see it was my Fortune to lose it: By your leave, Master. Fortune teller, I had a glimpse of you at home, at my Sisters the Widows, there you prophesied of the loss of a Chain: -- simply though I stand here, I was he that lost it.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Was it you, sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: On my troth, nuncle, he is is the rarest fellow, has told me my fortune so right; I find it so right to my nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: What is it? God send it a good one.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: O, it is a passing good one, Nuncle: for he says I shall prove such an excellent Gamester in my time, that I shall spend all faster than my Father got it.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: There is a Fortune indeed.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nay, it hits my humour so pat.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: aye, that will be the end of it: will the Curse of the Beggar prevail so much, that the son shall consume that foolishly, which the father got craftily; aye, aye, aye; it will , it will , it will .

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Stay, stay, stay.

div1.stage: Pyeboord with an Almanack, and the Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Turn over, George

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: June July here July, that is this month, Sunday thirteen, yesterday fourteen, today fifteen.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Look quickly for the fifteen day, -- if within the compass of these two days there would be some Boisterous storm or other, it would be the best, I had defer him off till then; some Tempest, if it be thy will.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Here is the fifteen day, -- Hot and fair.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Puh, would it had been, Hot and foul.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: The sixteen day, that is tomorrow; The morning for the most part, fair and pleasant.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No luck.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: But about high noon, Lightning and thunder.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: George Lightning and thunder? admirable! best of all! I will Conjure tomorrow just at hie none George,

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Happen but true tomorrow, Almanac, and I will give thee leave to lie all the year after.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir, I must crave your patience, to bestow this day upon me, that I may furnish myself strongly, -- I sent a Spirit into Lancashire the other day, to fetch back a knave Drover, and I look for his return this evening -- tomorrow morning, my friend here, and I will come and breakfast with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O, you shall be both most welcome.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And about noon, without fail, I purpose to Conjure.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Mid noon will be a fit time for you.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Conjuring, do you mean to Conjure at our house, tomorrow, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Marry do I, sir? it is my intent, young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: By my troth, I will love you while I live for it: rare Nicholas! we shall have Conjuring tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Puh aye, I could have told you of that.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Law, he could have told him of that, fool, coxcomb, could ye?

sp.speaker: Edm.
Cap.
sp.p: O, anything that is lost.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why look you, sir, I tell it you as a friend and a Conjurer; I should marry a Apothecaries Daughter, and it was told me, she lost her maidenhead at Stonie-Stratford now if you will do but so much as Conjure for it, and make all whole again --

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: That I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: By my troth I thank you, la.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A little merry with your sisters son, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O, a simple young man, very simple, come Captain, and you, sir; we will even part with a gallon of wine till tomorrow breakfast.

sp.speaker: Tip. Cap.
sp.p: Troth, agreed, sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Kinsman -- Scholar.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why now thou art a good Knave, worth a hundred Brownists.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Am I indeed, la: I thank you truly la.

div1.stage: Enter Moll, and Sir Iohn Penny-Dub.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: But I hope you will not serve a Knight so, Gentlewoman, will you? to cashier him, and cast him off at your pleasure; what do you think I was dubbed for nothing, no by my faith Ladies daughter.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Pray Sir John Penny-Dub let it be deferred awhile, I have a heart to marry as you can have; but as the Fortune teller told me.

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: Pox on the Fortune teller, would Derecke had been his fortune seven year ago, to cross my love thus: did he know what case I was in ? why this is able to make a man drown himself in his Fathers Fishpond.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And then he told me moreover, Sir Iohn, that the breach of it, kept my Father in Purgatory.

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: In Purgatory? why let him purge out his heart there, what have we to do with that ? there is Physicians enough there to cast his water, is that any matter to us ? how can he hinder our love? why let him be hanged now he is dead? -- Well, have I rid post day and night, to bring you merry news of my Fathers death, and now --

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Thy Fathers death? is the old Farmer dead?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: As dead as his Barn door, Moll

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And you will keep your word with me now, sir John that I shall have my Coach and my Coachman?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: Aye faith.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And two white Horses with black Feathers to draw it?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: Too.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: A guarded Lackey to run before it, and pied Liveries to come trashing after it.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Thou shalt Moll

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: And to let me have money in my purse to go whether I will.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: All this.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Then come, whatsoever comes of it, we will be made sure together before the Maids of the Kitchen.

div1.stage: Enter Widdow with her eldest Daughter, Franck and Frailtie.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now? where is my Brother Sir Godfrey went he forth this morning?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O no Madam, he is above at breakfast, with sir reverence a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A Conjurer? what manner of fellow is he?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O, a wondrous rare fellow, Mistress, very strongly made upward, for he goes in a Buff jerkin: he says he will fetch Sir Godfreys Chain again, if it hang between heaven and earth.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What he will not? then he is an excellent fellow I warrant, how happy were that woman to be blessed with such a Husband, a man of cunning? how does he look Frailty, very swartly I warrant, with black beard, scorched cheeks, and smoky eyebrows.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Faugh -- he is neither smoke dried, nor scorched, nor black, nor nothing, I tell you, Madam, he looks as fair to see to, as one of us ; I do think but if you saw him once, you would take him to be a Christian.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: So fair, and yet so cunning, that is to be wondered at, mother.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Oliuer Muck-hill, and Sir Andrew Tip-staffe.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Bless you sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: And you, fair Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Gods, what do you mean, Gentlemen? fie, did I not give you your answers?

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Sweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, I will not stick with you for a kiss, Daughter, kiss the Gentleman for once.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: I am proud of such a favour.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Truly la, sir Oliuer you are much to blame to come again when you know my mind, so well delivered -- as a Widow could deliver a thing.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: But I expect a farther comfort, Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why la you now, did I not desire you to put off your suit quite and clean when you came to me again? how say you? did I not?

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: But the sincere love which my heart bears you --

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go to, I will cut you off; and Sir Oliuer to put you in comfort, afar off, my fortune is read me, I must marry again.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: O blessed fortune!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But not as long as I can choose; -- nay, I will hold out well.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now? what is the haste?

sp.speaker: Tipst.
sp.p: Faith, Mistress I will maintain you gallantly, I will bring you to Court, wean you among the fair society of Ladies poor Kinswomen of mine in cloth of Silver, beside you shall have your Monkey, your Parrot, your Muscat, and your Piss, Piss, Piss.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: It will do very well.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, does he mean to Conjure here then? how shall I do to be rid of these Knights, -- please you Gentlemen to walk a while in the Garden, go gather a pink, or a lily flower.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: With all our hearts, Lady, and count us favoured.

sp.speaker: Sir God. within.
sp.p: Step in Nicholas look, is the coast clear?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O, as clear as a Cats eye, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Then enter Captain Conjurer: -- now -- how like you your Room, sir?

div1.stage: Enter Sir Godfrey, Capt. Pyb, Edm, Nick.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O wonderful convenient.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I can tell you, Captain, simply though it lies here, it is the fairest Room in my Mothers house, as dainty a Room to Conjure in, methinks, -- why you may bid, I cannot tell how many devils welcome in it; my Father has had twenty here at once!

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: What devils?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Devils, no Deputies, and the wealthiest men he could get.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Nay put by your chats now, fall to your business roundly, the fescue of the Dial is upon the criss-cross of Noon: but o, hear me, Captain, a qualm comes over my stomach.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: O, how if the devil should prove a knave, and tear the hangings.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Faugh, I warrant you, Sir Godfrey

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: aye, Nuncle, or spit fire upon the ceiling.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Very true too, for it is but thin plastered, and it will quickly take hold on the laths: and if he chance to spit downward too, he will burn all the boards.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: My life for yours, Sir Godfrey

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: My sister is very curious and dainty over this room I can tell and therefore if he must needs spit, I pray desire him to spit in the Chimney.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why, assure you, sir Godfrey he shall not be brought up with so little manners, to spit and spawl on the flower.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Why I thank you, good Captain, pray have a care aye, fall to your Circle, we will not trouble you I warrant you, come, we will in to the next room, and because we will be sure to keep him out there, we will bar up the door with some of the Godliest Zealous works.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: That will be a fine device, Nuncle; and because the ground shall be as holy as the door, I will tear two or three Rosaries in pieces, and strew the leaves about the Chamber: O! the Devil already.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: 'sfoot, Captain, speak somewhat for shame: it lightens and; thunders before thou wilt begin, why when?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Pray peace George, -- thou wilt make me laugh anon, and spoil all.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O, now it begins again; now, now, now! Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Rumbos -- ragdayon, purr, purr, colucundrion, Hois -- Plois

div1.stage: Sir Godfrey through the key-hole, within.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O admirable Conjurer! has fetched Thunder already.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Hark hark, again Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Benjamino, -- gaspois -- kay -- gosgothoteron -- umbrois

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O, I would the Devil would come away quickly, he has no conscience to put a man to such pain.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Again.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Flowste -- kakopumpos -- dragon -- leloomenos -- hodgepodge.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Well said, Captain.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: So long a-coming? O would I had never begun it now, for I fear me these roaring tempests will destroy all the fruits of the earth, and tread upon my corn -- O, in the Country.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Gog de gog, hobgoblin, hunks, hounslow, hockley to come park.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O brother, brother, what a tempest is in the Garden, sure there is some Conjuration abroad.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: It is at home, sister.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: By and by I will step in, Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nunck -- Nunck -- Rip -- Gascoines, Ips, Drip -- Dropite.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: He drips and drops, poor man: alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Now, I come.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O Sulphur Soot face

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Arch Conjurer, what wouldst thou with me?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O, the Devil, sister, in the dining Chamber: sing sister, I warrant you that will keep him out; quickly, quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: So, so, so ; I will release thee: enough Captain, enough: allow us some time to laugh a little, they are shuddering and shaking by this time, as if an Earthquake were in their kidneys.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sirrah George, how was it, how was it? did I it well enough?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: wilt believe me, Captain, better than any Conjurer, for here was no harm in this; and yet their horrible expectation satisfied well, you were much beholding to Thunder and Lightning at this time, it gracest you well I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I must needs say so George? sirrah if we could have convoyed hither cleanly a cracker, or a fire-wheel, it had been admirable.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Blurt, blurt, there is nothing remains to put thee to pain now, Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Pain? I protest George, my heels are sorer than a Whison Morris dancer.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: All is past now, -- only to reveal that the chain is in the Garden, where, thou knowest, it has lain these two days.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: But I fear, that fox Nicholas has revealed it already.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Fear not, Captain, you must put it to the venture now: Nay it is time, call upon them, take pity on them, for I believe some of them are in a pitiful case by this time.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir Godfrey? Nicholas, Kinsman, -- 'sfoot they are fast at it still George, Sir Godfrey?:

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O, is that the devils voice? how comes he to know my name?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fear not, Sir Godfrey all is quieted.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: What, is he laid?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Laid: and has newly dropped Your chain in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: In the Garden! in our Garden?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Your Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O sweet Conjurer! whereabouts there?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Look well about a bank of Rosemary.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Sister, the Rosemary bank, come, come; there is my chain he says.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O happiness! run, run.

div1.stage: supposed to goe. Edm. at key-hole.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Captain Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Who? Master Edmond

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: aye, Master Edmond may I come in safely without danger, think you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Puh, long ago, it is all, as it was at first:
Fear nothing, pray come near, -- how now, man?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: O! this room is mightily hot in faith: 'slid, my shirt sticks to my Belly already, what a steam the Rogue has left behind him? foh, this room must be aired Gentlemen it smells horribly of Brimstone, -- let us open the windows.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Faith, Master Edmond it is but your conceit.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I would you could make me believe that, in faith, why do you think I cannot smell his savour, from another: yet I take it kindly from you, because you would not put me in a fear, in faith: on my troth I shall love you for this the longest day of my life.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Puh, it is nothing, Sir, love me when you see more.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Mass, now I remember, I will look whether he has singed the hangings, or no.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Captain, to entertain a little sport till they come: make him believe, you will charm him invisible, he is apt to admire anything, you see, let me alone to give force to it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: go, retire to yonder end then.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I protest you are a rare fellow, are you not?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O Master Edmond you know but the least part of me yet; why now at this instant I could but flourish my wand thrice over your head, and charm you invisible.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: What you could not? make me walk invisible man? I should laugh at that in faith; troth I will require your kindness, if you will it, good Captain Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay, I should hardly deny you such a small kindness, Master Edmond Plus why, look you, sir, it is no more but this, and thus again, and now you are invisible.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Am I faith? who would think it?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You see the fortune teller yonder at farther end of the chamber, go toward him, do what you will with him, he shall never find you.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Say you so, I will try that in faith, --

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: How now, Captain? who is that jostled me?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Jostled you? I saw nobody.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, -- say it was a spirit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Shall I? -- maybe some spirit that haunt the circle.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O my nose, again, pray conjure then Captain.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Troth this is excellent, I may do any knavery now and never be seen, -- and now I remember me, Sir Godfrey my Uncle abused me the other day, and told tales of me to my Mother -- Troth now I am invisible, I will hit him a sound wherret on the ear, when he comes out of the garden, -- I may be revenged on him now finely.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Godfrey, Widdow, Franck, Nicholas with the Chaine.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I have my Chain again, my Chain is found again,
O sweet Captain, O admirable Conjurer.
O, what mean you by that, Nephew?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nephew? I hope you do not know me, Uncle?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why did you strike your Uncle, sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why Captain, am I not invisible?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A good jest George, -- not now you are not sir,
Why did you not see me, when I did uncharm you?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Not I by my troth, Captain:
Then pray you pardon me, Uncle,
I thought I had been invisible when I struck you.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: So, you would do it? go, -- you are a foolish boy,
If were I not overcome with greater joy,
I would make you taste correction.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Correction, push -- no, neither you nor my Mother, shall think to whip me as you have done.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Captain, my joy is such, I know not how to thank you, let me embrace you, hug you, O my sweet Chain, gladness even makes me giddy, rare man: it was just in the Rosemary bank, as if one should have laid it there, -- O cunning, cunning!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, seeing my fortune tells me I must marry: let me marry a man of wit, a man of parts, here is a worthy Captain, and it is a fine Title truly la to be a Captains Wife, a Captains Wife, it goes very finely, beside all the world knows that a worthy Captain, is a fit Companion to any Lord, then why not a sweet bedfellow for any Lady, -- I will have it so --

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O Mistress, Gentlemen, there is the bravest sight coming along this way.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What brave sight?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O, one going to burying, and another going to hanging.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A rueful sight.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: 'Sfoot Captain, I will pawn my life the Corporal is coffined, and old Skirmish the soldier going to execution, and it is now full about the time of his walking; hold out a little longer sleepy potion, and we shall have excellent admiration; for I will take upon me the cure of him.

div1.stage: Enter the Coffin of the Corporall, the souldier bound, and led by Officers, the Sheriffe there,

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O here they come, here they come!

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Now must I close secretly with the Soldier, prevent his impatience, or else all is discovered.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O lamentable seeing, these were those Brothers, that fought and bled before our door.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: What they were not, Sister?

sp.speaker: Skirm.
sp.p: George, look to it, I will peach at Tyburne else.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Mum, -- Gentles all, vouchsafe me audience, and you especially Master Sheriff:
Yon man is bound to execution,
Because he wounded this that now lies coffined?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: True, true, he shall have the law, -- and I know the law.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: But under favour, Master Sheriff, if this man had been cured and safe again, he should have been released then?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Why, make you question of that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Then I release him freely, and will take upon me the death that he should die, if within a little season, I do not cure him to his proper health again.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: How sir? recover a dead man?
That were most strange of all.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sweet sir, I love you dearly, and could wish my best part yours, -- O do not undertake such an impossible venture.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Love you me; then for your sweet sake I will it: Let me entreat the corps to be set down.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Bearers set down the Coffin, -- this is wonderful, and worthy Stoes Chronicle.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: I pray bestow the freedom of the air upon our wholesome Art, -- Mass his cheeks begin to receive natural warmth: nay good Corporal wake betime, or I shall have a longer sleep than you, -- 'sfoot if he should prove dead indeed now, he were fully revenged upon me for making a property of him, yet I had rather run upon the Ropes, than have the Rope like a Tetter run upon me, O -- he stirs -- he stirs again -- look Gentlemen, he recovers, he starts, he rises.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: O, o, defend us -- out alas.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay pray be still; you will make him more giddy else, -- he knows no body yet.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'swounds: who am I? covered with snow? I marvel?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay, I knew he would swear the first thing he did, as soon as ever he came to his life again.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: 'sfoot Hostess -- some hot porridge, -- O, o, lay on a dozen of Faggots in the Moon Parlour, there.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Lady, you must needs take a little pity of him in faith, and send him in to your Kitchen fire.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, with all my heart sir, Nicholas and Frailty help to bear him in.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Bear him in, quoth he, pray call out the Maids, I shall never have the heart to it indeed la.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Nor I neither, I cannot abide to handle a Ghost of all men.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Sblood, let me see, where was I drunk last night, heh --

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, shall I bid you once again take him away.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Why, we are as fearful as you I warrant you -- O --

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Away villains, bid the maids make him a Caudle presently to settle his brain -- or a posset of Sack, quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Sir, whatosever you are, I do more than admire you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O aye, if you knew all, Master Sheriff, as you shall do, you would say then, that here were two of the rarest men within the walls of Christendom.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Two of them, O wonderful: Officers I discharge you, set him free, all is in tune.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: aye, and a banquet ready by this time, Master Sheriff, to which I most cheerfully invite you, and your late prisoner there: see you this goodly Chain, sir, mun, no more words, it was lost and is found again; come, my inestimable Bullies, we will talk of your noble Acts in sparkling Charnico, and instead of a Jester, we will have the Ghost in the white sheet sit at upper end of the Table.

sp.speaker: Sheriffe.
sp.p: Excellent merry man in faith.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.l: Well, seeing I am enjoined to love and marry,
My foolish vow thus I cashier to air
Which first begot it, -- now love play thy part;
The Scholar reads his lecture in my heart.

div1.stage: Enter in hast Maister Edmond and Frayltie.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: This is the Marriage morning for my Mother and my Sister.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O me, Master Edmond we shall have rare doings.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nay go Frailty, run to the Sexton, you know my mother will be married at Saint Antlings, hie thee, it is past five, bid them open the Church door, my Sister is almost ready.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What all ready, Master Edmond

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nay go hie thee, first run to the Sexton, and run to the Clarke, and then run to Master Pigman the Parson, and then run to the Milliner and then run home again.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Here is run, run, run --

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: But hark Frailty,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What, more yet?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Has the Maids remembered to strew the way to the Church.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Faugh, an hour ago I help them myself.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Away, away, away, away then.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Away, away, away, away, then.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I shall have a simple father-in-law, a brave Captain able to beat all our street: Captain Idle now my Lady Mother will be fitted for a delicate name, my Lady Idle, my Lady Idle, the finest name that can be for a woman, and then the Scholar, Master Pie-boord for my Sister Francis, that will be Mistress Francis Pie-boord, Mistress Francis Pie-Boord, they will keep a good Table I warrant you: Now all the Knights noses are put out of joint, they may go to a Bone setters now.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Hark, hark; o who comes here with two Torches before them, my sweet Captain, and my fine Scholar? o how bravely they are shot up in one night, they look like fine Britains now methinks, here is a gallant change in faith; 'slid, they have hired men and all by the Clock.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Master Edmund kind, honest, dainty Master Edmond

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Faugh, sweet Captain father-in-law, a rare perfume i'faith.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: What, are the Brides stirring? may we steal upon them thinkst thou, Master Edmond

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Faugh, they are even upon readiness I can assure you: for they were at their Torch even now, by the same token I tumbled down the stairs.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Alas, poor Master Edmond

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O, the Musicians! I prithee, Master Edmond call them in and liquor them a little.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: That I will, sweet Captain father-in-law, and make each of them as drunk as a common fiddler.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Penidub, and Moll aboue lacing of her clothes.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Whewh, Mistress Moll, Mistress Moll

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: It is I.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Who, Sir John Penidub, O you are an early Cock i'faith, who would have thought you to be so rare a stirrer?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: prithee Moll, let me come up.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: No by my faith Sir Iohn I will keep you down, for you Knights are very dangerous if once you get above.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I will not stay in faith.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: in faith you shall stay: for, Sir Iohn you must note the nature of the Climates: your Northern Wench in her own Country may well hold out till she be fifteen, but if she touch the South once, and come up to London, here the Chimes go presently after twelve.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: O thou art a mad Wench Moll, but I prithee make haste, for the Priest is gone before.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Do you follow him, I will not be long after.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Oliver Muck-hill, Sir Andrew Tip-staffe, and old Skirmish talking.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: O monstrous unheard of forgery.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: Knight, I never heard of such villainy in our own Country, in my life.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Why it is impossible. dare you maintain your words?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Dare we ? even to their weasand pipe: we know all their plots, they cannot squander with us, they have knavishly abused us, made only properties of us to advance theirselves upon our shoulders, but they shall rue their abuses, this morning they are to be married.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: It is too true, yet if the Widow be not too much besotted on slights and forgeries, the revelation of their villainies will make them loathsome, and to that end, be it in private to you, I sent late last night to an honourable personage, to whom I am much indebted in kindness, as he is to me, and therefore presume upon the payment of his tongue, and that he will lay out good words for me, and to speak truth, for such needful occasions, I only preserve him in bond, and sometimes he may do me more good here in the City by a free word of his mouth, than if he had paid one half in hand, and took Doomsday for the other.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: In troth, sir, without soothing be it spoken, you have published much judgment in these few words.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: For you know, what such a man utters will be thought effectual and to weighty purpose, and therefore into his mouth we will put the approved theme of their forgeries.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: And I will maintain it, Knight, if she will' be true.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: How now fellow.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: May it please you, sir, my Lord is newly lighted from his Coach.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.l: Is my Lord come already? his honour is early:
You see he loves me well; up before seven,
Trust me, I have found him night capped at eleven:
There is good hope yet: come, I will relate all to him.

div1.stage: Enter the two Bridegroomes, Captaine and Scholler after them, Sir Godfrey and Edmond, Widdow chandged in apparell, Mistris Francis led betweene two Knights, Sir Iohn Penny-dub and Moll: there meetes them a Noble man, Sir Oliver Muckil, and Sir Andrew Tip-staffe.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: By your leave, Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My Lord, your honour is most chastely welcome.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Madam, though I came now from Court, I come not to flatter you: upon whom can I justly cast this blot, but upon your own forehead, that know not Ink from Milk, such is the blind besotting in the state of an unheaded woman that is a Widow. For it is the property of all you that are Widows (a handful excepted) to hate those that honestly and carefully love you, to the maintenance of credit, state, and posterity, and strongly to dote on those, that only love you to undo you: who regard you least are best regarded; who hate you most, are best beloved. And if there be but one man amongst, ten thousand millions of men, that is accursed, disastrous, and evilly Planeted; whom Fortune beats most, whom God hates most, and all Societies esteem least, that man is sure to be a Husband -- Such is the peevish Moon that rules your bloods. An impudent fellow best woes you, a flattering lip best wins you, or in a mirth, who talks roughliest, is most sweetest; nor can you distinguish truth from forgeries, mists from simplicity: witness those two deceitful Monsters, that you have entertained for Bridegrooms.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Deceitful --

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: All will out.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: 'sfoot who has blabbed George, that foolish Nicholas

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: For, what they have besotted your easy blood withal, were naught but forgeries, the Fortune telling for Husbands, and the Conjuring for the Chain; Sir Godfrey heard the falsehood of all: nothing but mere knavery, deceit, and cozenage.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O wonderful! indeed I wondered that my Husband with all his craft, could not keep himself out of Purgatory:

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: And I more wonder, that my Chain should be gone, and my Taylor had none of it.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And I wondered most of all, that I should be tied from Marriage, having such a mind to it: come Saint Iohn Pennydub fair weather on our side, the Moon has changed since yesternight.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: The Sting of every evil is within me.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: And that you may perceive I feign not with you, behold their fellow actor in those forgeries, who full of Spleen and envy at their so sudden advancements, revealed all their Plot in anger.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Base Soldier, to reveal us.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Is it possible we should be blinded so, and our eyes open?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Widow, will you now believe that false, which too soon you believed true?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, to my shame, I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: But under favour, my Lord, my Chain was truly lost, and strangely found again.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Resolve him of that, Soldier.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: In few words, Knight, then thou wert the arch gull of all.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Nay I will prove it: for the Chain was but hid in the Rosemary bank all this while, and thou gottest him out of prison to Conjure for it, who did it admirably fustianly, for indeed what need any others, when he knew where it was?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O villainy of villainies! but how came my Chain there?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Where is, truly la, Indeed la? he that will not Swear, but lie; he that will not Steal, but Rob: pure Nicholas Saint Antlings

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: O villain! one of our Society,
Deemed always holy, pure, religious:
A Puritan, a thief? when was it ever hard?
Sooner we will kill a man, than Steal, thou knowest
. Out Slave, I will rend my Lion from thy back -- with mine own hands.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Dear Master, o.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Nay Knight, dwell in patience. And now, Widow, being so near the Church, it were great pity, nay uncharity to send you home again without a Husband: draw nearer, you of true Worship, state and credit, that should not stand so far off from a Widow, and suffer forged shapes to come between you: Not that in these I blemish the true Title of a Captain, or blot the fair margent of a Scholar: for I honour worthy and deserving parts in the one, and cherish fruitful Virtues in the other. Come Lady, and you Virgin, bestow your eyes and your purest affections, upon men of estimation, both in Court and City, that hath long wooed you, and both with their hearts and wealth, sincerely love you.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Good sister, do: sweet little Frank these are men of reputation, you shall be welcome at Court: a great credit for a Citizen, sweet sister.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Come, her silence does consent to it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I know not with what face.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Pah, pah, with your own face, they desire no other.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pardon me, worthy Sirs, I and my daughter have wronged your loves.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: It is easily pardoned, Lady,
If you vouchsafe it now.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: With all my soul.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And I, Sir Iohn with soul, heart, lights and all.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: They are all mine, Moll

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Now, Lady:
What honest Spirit, but will applaud your choice,
And gladly furnish you with hand and voice;
A happy change, which makes even heaven rejoice.
Come, enter into your Joys, you shall not want,
For fathers now, I doubt it not, believe me,
But that you shall have hands enough to give.
